div.head: To the courteous, not captious Reader, health.
div.p: I Make no doubt, but there are many of my countrymen which haue seene the beautie and riches both of Paris and Venice, who may happily blame me for my breefe description. But gentle reader I answere it thus, I could Willingly haue giuen them a larger praise, had their merrit beene equall with Londons: And this moreouer I desire those which shall mislike my Labour to mend it, and none shall be more willing and ready to applaude them then my selfe. I haue begun the foundation, if any please to build vppon it, I shall thanke him for beautyfiing my rough building, But hoping they will iudge of me, as I would doe of them in this case, I leaue it to their mildest and most fauourable censure.
